sn8.1:1.2: At one time Venerable Vaṅgīsa was staying near Āḷavī, at the Aggāḷava Tree-shrine, together with his mentor, Venerable Nigrodhakappa.
sn8.1:1.3: Now at that time Vaṅgīsa was junior, recently gone forth. He had been left behind to look after the dwelling.
sn8.1:1.4: Then several women dressed in all their finery went to the monastery at Aggāḷava in order to inspect the dwelling.
sn8.1:1.5: When Vaṅgīsa saw them he became dissatisfied, with lust infecting his mind.
sn8.1:1.8: that I’ve become dissatisfied, with lust infecting my mind. How is it possible for someone else to dispel my discontent and give rise to satisfaction?
sn8.1:1.9: Why don’t I do it myself?”
sn8.1:1.10: Then, on the occasion of dispelling his own discontent and giving rise to satisfaction, he recited these verses:
sn8.1:2.4: by the rude thoughts of the Dark One.
sn8.1:3.1: Even if a thousand mighty princes and great archers,
sn8.1:4.4: for I stand firm in the teaching.
sn8.1:5.1: I heard this with my own ears
sn8.1:5.2: from the Buddha, Kinsman of the Sun,
sn8.1:5.3: about the path going to extinguishment;
sn8.1:6.1: Wicked One, if you come near me
sn8.1:6.3: I’ll make sure that you, Death,
sn8.1:6.4: won’t even see the path I take.”
